repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Industrial Investment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Industrial
            Investment Credit Project for Pakistan was marginally
            satisfactory. The project achieved most of its objectives,
            its impact on institutional development was modest, and
            sustainability is likely. However, the performance of both
            the Bank and Borrower was marginally satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, future
            credits should be reinforced by systematic sector reforms
            that specifically address the elements jeopardizing PFIs
            soundness. Second, the Bank and GOP should develop and
            support financial sector policy reforms that will provide
            the sector with the right incentive framework. Third, in the
            case of financial intermediary operations, successful
            project implementation depends on careful monitoring of the
            PFIs and close supervision of subprojects as soon as
            problems arise. Fourth, the market determination of interest
            rates is an essential element of competition and efficiency
            in the financial sector. Finally, the quantity and quality
            of an economy's industrial investment are critical in
            terms of its growth and efficiency.

docna.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Industrial Investment
            Credit Project

display_title.display_title:
Pakistan - Second Industrial
            Investment Credit Project

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Industrial Investment
            Credit (IIC) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Industrial Investment Credit
            Project will support the Government's efforts to
            promote private industrial investment and will help the GOP
            strengthen the financial markets. It will: (a) assist in
            development of a more efficient capital market so as to
            increase the sources of equity finance for industry; (b)
            stimulate further competition among Participating Financial
            Institutions (PFIs); (c) ensure a steady flow of term
            finance to private industry; and (d) continue the
            institution building programs of the PFIs. The project will
            stimulate private savings and finance 40 to 45 subprojects,
            which will be expected to create about 30,000 new jobs. The
            major project risk is that economic conditions, and hence
            investor confidence, will be hurt by political and/or
            economic uncertainties and insufficient Government action to
            maintain the pace of structural adjustment. Recent GOP
            policy measures suggest that the Government is committed to
            a further expansion of the role of the private sector in the economy.

docna.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Industrial Investment
            Credit (IIC) Project

display_title.display_title:
Pakistan - Second Industrial
            Investment Credit (IIC) Project
